snippet.textDisplay: Videos like this are so awesome for the public conversation. Way to fight bad info with good info, Dr. Mike! I was just accepted to an osteopathic school in Texas. I want to be a DO like you!

snippet.textDisplay:
My problem is with prescribing antidepressants when people are better helped in the long term with psychotherapy like CBT. And that’s something only a psychologist or psychiatrist can provide.

People end up mentally and physically dependent on these drugs, even though often they didn’t help for their symptoms
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
Sure, send everyone to a mental specialist (put all those low risk patients with the ones who have REALLY HUGE problems), inb4 only 20000 certified specialists in the US while there are more than 66 mil cases (because not everyone wants to admit they have a problem or talk about it so the numbers are actually higher) who need treatment...

Ya, I see how that can be a problem. Kinda like a queue at the supermarket that stretches to the exit.

snippet.textDisplay: People don't self diagnose themselves with medical conditions before going to a doctor, so why do they do it with mental health?
snippet.textOriginal: People don't self diagnose themselves with medical conditions before going to a doctor, so why do they do it with mental health?

snippet.textDisplay: As a fellow general practitioner (primary care physician/family physician) -- thank you for addressing this. I agree with absolutely everything you've said, and you said it so eloquently!! Thanks Dr Mike!
snippet.textOriginal: As a fellow general practitioner (primary care physician/family physician) -- thank you for addressing this. I agree with absolutely everything you've said, and you said it so eloquently!! Thanks Dr Mike!

snippet.textDisplay: As someone who has struggled with depression and anxiety for a large portion of my life. Having a personal, already well developed relationship with my Doctor made my ability to explain my condition much easier and more comfortable. While specialists have been great, my Doc has never steered me wrong. Thanks Dr. Mike

snippet.textDisplay: My pcp did prescribe me an antidepressant without asking any family history or anything. I didn’t respond well to it. When I spoke with a psychiatrist, I got a good round of questions that got me on the right medication and dose. My pcp didn’t seem to know what she was doing 😞
snippet.textOriginal: My pcp did prescribe me an antidepressant without asking any family history or anything. I didn’t respond well to it. When I spoke with a psychiatrist, I got a good round of questions that got me on the right medication and dose. My pcp didn’t seem to know what she was doing 😞

snippet.textDisplay:
What he doesn't say is how many "doctors" misdiagnose, and are way too quick to prescribe medication that that gets taken for years and years and ends up with dementia. The best docs I know of put the Bible first, and then scientifically based medicine next if necessary.

I've been to some clinics and providers that was nothing short of nightmarish--the last crummy clinic had an untrained nurse giving vaccines too high on the shoulder and she blew a hole in my shoulder labrum area--MRI and others scans say so. But according to these idiot so-called doctors and providers, I was lying about it and just wanted to sue them--no wonder they went completely out of practice last year!

This guy is dreaming--please come down to the real world--according to him--family practitioners can do no wrong.

snippet.textDisplay: As a behavioural scientist I would have appreciated some more emphasis on other options than medication, but understand that that may be a reaction to the specific statement. Although I know under treatment is a huge problem, I am still shocked at the American numbers. How are so few professionals available to take care of so many! We desperately need innovation in this field!
snippet.textOriginal: As a behavioural scientist I would have appreciated some more emphasis on other options than medication, but understand that that may be a reaction to the specific statement. Although I know under treatment is a huge problem, I am still shocked at the American numbers. How are so few professionals available to take care of so many! We desperately need innovation in this field!

snippet.textDisplay: My primary care prescribed me lexipro when I was 20 and depressed and anxious because I had undiagnosed adhd
snippet.textOriginal: My primary care prescribed me lexipro when I was 20 and depressed and anxious because I had undiagnosed adhd

snippet.textDisplay: My girlfriend's primary care giver. Her pediatrist who she's been seeing for years was prescribing her zolpimed for years for her insomnia. It took me 30 seconds to figure out this is madness. She later was diagnosed with heart arythmia - bradycardia. So you're statement that primary care givers should always be trusted with psychological treatments is wrong.
snippet.textOriginal: My girlfriend's primary care giver. Her pediatrist who she's been seeing for years was prescribing her zolpimed for years for her insomnia. It took me 30 seconds to figure out this is madness. She later was diagnosed with heart arythmia - bradycardia. So you're statement that primary care givers should always be trusted with psychological treatments is wrong.

snippet.textDisplay: I think what's most important is that specialists are... well, specialised. This is more valid for physical issues than psychological, but still. I've been to a ton of specialists and each of them ONLY looks at their own speciality, instead of looking at the whole picture and checking whether maybe the different issues I have are related. I'd love to have a GP/Primary Care Doctor who actually has an overview of all of my symptoms from the various fields to make some connections. Unfortunately, mine doesn't do that (or much at all, really, unless she's told exactly what it is that you want done), but I'm looking into getting a better one.
